title: How can I more clearly explain to bronze players that cs > kills?
body:
I've been told 3 times this week now that "cs doesn't matter".

Despite me usually having less kills than these people, I'm still multiple levels ahead.

The message isn't getting across. Having higher levels, more xp and more gold just for killing a few more minions is not getting into the heads of these teammates.

And you want to know the worst part? The guy who told me cs doesn't matter once this week is ranked ahead of me on one of my accounts. He's also doing Jungle Shyvana. Yes, a Jungle Shyvana is telling me that CS is not relevant to anything in the game.

I'm in Silver and I have good friends in Gold and we all have different strengths and weaknesses. A friend of mine who just hit Gold for this season today has really poor game knowledge and generally doesn't think about game functionality a lot, but he's really great mechanically and largely how to win fights. My other friend has great knowledge and great mechanics so he's hoping to get to Plat soon. Personally I have quite a lot of knowledge but I don't have enough experience so I struggle to know how to approach matchups and my mechanics are lacking too. 

There's no universal level of game knowledge, it's very possible to be at least somewhat ignorant of the game no matter what your level. Some Bronze players know a lot but don't know what to do with that knowledge, but not all.

Practice and research dude. Matchups are one of the easiest things to get the hang of if you are an intelligent player. Figure out how their champion's trading pattern works.

For example, Graves top verses a melee with a gap closer.

Graves is ranged and has burst, vision denial, mobility, and resists. So he's a bit of a ranged bruiser. However, he has very short range and his auto attacks can be semi-mitigated by minions. In addition, his ammo system makes him vulnerable after he uses both of his shots.

Solution: In order to win this lane as a melee champion, you want someone that can jump in, deal some damage (preferably really good burst), then dip out to mitigate counter harass. Champions that favor extended trades with auto attacks will struggle because Graves will have enough time to get his auto attacks and dash up in order to out trade.

So Jax, Renekton, and Wukong can excel against Graves.

Jax can Empower-Leapstrike (WQ) into auto for 3rd damage proc (if lvl 6+) and then go for extended all in with E due to it's unique safety it provides, or use it as cover to prevent damage return. Ulti also useful to help prevent raw damage from bursting Jax.

Renekton has a shit load of damage and two dashes, making it fully possible to quickly jump in, nuke, and jump out to help mitigate the return trade. He also has natural sustain and innate tankiness to help prevent bursting.

Wukong can dash in with EQ and nuke Graves, though not as effectively as Jax or Renekton, but can safely disengage with W. Mana intensive, but can scale into late game harder than Renekton (Who falls off), but not as hard as Jax. Makes up for it with his passive giving him resists and having way better teamfight presence than either of them.

Someone that's bad against Graves is someone like Riven.

She's innately squishy and her gap closers that are also tied into her damage are also mitigated by Graves' dash, which also helps prevent her execute because it effectively mitigates her damage twice (Initial damage, reducing % missing, then the % missing reduction on the phys. execute) - He can simply dash away in order to get reload and deal very significant damage when she attempts to flee.

These are just bare examples of matchup specifics, and of course jungle intervention and individual outplays and misplays can go into account.

It's a balancing act really. When ya lane you have three goals in mind.

1) get tons of gold as fast as possible.
2) slow your opponents gold farming to ensure a gold lead.
3) apply pressure in lane so your opponent can't leave without risking their tower.

Kills are valued so highly because they can achomplish all three in one action, but the risk to going for kills is falling behind in gold do to getting nothing while your opponent farmed successfully.

In low elo, cs seems inefficient only if your opponent is successful in getting kills. Best way to counter this is to play safe and prioritize survival and assume the worst in every situation. Assume they have vision, assume their jungler is around the corner ready to gank. Unless you know for certain that nothing could go wrong (vision, mini map, etc) Don't take the unnecessary risk. Eventually their thirst for kills will lead to starving for gold and you can turn the tables.
